unnormalised: Okay, so someone asked about the time difference between India and the US. It's kinda tricky 'cause the US has multiple time zones, right? India has only 1: IST (Indian Standard Time), which is GMT+5:30. Makes things simpler, doesn't it?
normalised: Okay, so someone asked about the time difference between India and the U-S. It's kind of tricky because the U-S has multiple time zones, right? India has only one: I-S-T (Indian Standard Time), which is G-M-T plus five hours and thirty minutes. Makes things simpler, doesn't it?

unnormalised: See, if you're calling someone in New York, which follows EST (Eastern Standard Time), they're GMT-5. So, the difference is 10 hours and 30 minutes. India is ahead. Meaning if it's 8 PM here in Mumbai, it's only 9:30 AM in New York City. Confusing, I know!
normalised: See, if you're calling someone in New York, which follows E-S-T (Eastern Standard Time), they're G-M-T minus five. So, the difference is ten hours and thirty minutes. India is ahead. Meaning if it's eight P-M here in Mumbai, it's only nine thirty A-M in New York City. Confusing, I know!

unnormalised: But then, California, which is on PST (Pacific Standard Time), is GMT-8. That makes it a whopping 13 hours and 30 minutes difference. So, 8 PM in Delhi equals 6:30 AM in Los Angeles. And during daylight savings, these figures will change by an hour.
normalised: But then, California, which is on P-S-T (Pacific Standard Time), is G-M-T minus eight. That makes it a whopping thirteen hours and thirty minutes difference. So, eight P-M in Delhi equals six thirty A-M in Los Angeles. And during daylight savings, these figures will change by an hour.

unnormalised: Honestly, I always double-check before calling folks abroad. Websites like timeanddate.com are lifesavers. Otherwise, you might end up waking someone up at 3 AM! Nobody wants that, especially not your cousin whoâ€™s studying at UCLA. Remember to convert those times before any important calls or meetings!
normalised: Honestly, I always double check before calling folks abroad. Websites like time and date dot com are lifesavers. Otherwise, you might end up waking someone up at three A-M! Nobody wants that, especially not your cousin who's studying at U-C-L-A. Remember to convert those times before any important calls or meetings!
